K-9.source: BC Science K-9 Classroom Assessment Resource Package

K-2: Observe familiar contexts; ask simple questions; make basic predictions.
3-4: Ask investigable questions; predict based on prior knowledge.
5-6: Ask questions leading to scientific inquiries; predict outcomes.
7-8: Formulate more complex questions and predictions.
9: Ask testable questions; make precise observations; begin forming hypotheses.

procedures_and_evidence.description: Planning, safe use of materials, data collection.

K-2: Use materials safely; gather simple data.
3-4: Plan simple investigations; sort and classify data.
5-6: Choose methods; investigate a variable; record data.
7-8: Control variables; use tools to collect and organize data.
9: Plan and use varied methods; collect reliable data from multiple sources.

analysis.description: Patterns, conclusions, errors, evaluation of sources.

K-2: Represent simple data; talk about observations.
3-4: Identify patterns; relate predictions to results.
5-6: Use data to support conclusions; refine methods.
7-8: Identify error sources; evaluate ideas from evidence.
9: Evaluate methods, error, bias; draw data-consistent conclusions.

K-3: Consider environmental impact of own actions.
7-9: Identify and evaluate ethical, social, and environmental implications of science topics.

K-3: Share observations and ideas about place and phenomena.
4-6: Explain ideas and processes with simple representations.
7-9: Communicate clearly using appropriate science language and models.

10-12.source: BC Science 10-12 Classroom Assessment Resource Package

questioning.description: Testable and increasingly abstract scientific questions; justified predictions and hypotheses.

procedures_and_evidence.description: Designing investigations, selecting methods, collecting high-quality data from varied sources.

analyzing_and_evaluating.description: Analyzing relationships, drawing evidence-based conclusions, evaluating methods, uncertainty, and models.

perspectives_and_ethics.description: Considering environmental, ethical, economic, technological impacts; including First Peoples perspectives.

communication.description: Using precise scientific language, models, and formats to communicate for specific audiences.
